awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Characterization of Subduction Channel Processes - Borehole Sampling at Active Serpentinite Mud Volcanoes on the Mariana Forearc
awd_abstract_narration:
The Mariana Trench is the deepest location on Earth, resulting from the subduction of the Pacific Plate under the Philippine Plate. Fluids that were trapped in the pores and minerals of the Pacific Plate are liberated during this subduction. These fluids react with rock in the overriding Philippine Plate to produce a slurry of mud and fluids that are very alkaline (with a pH up to 12.5, more alkaline than Clorox), yet support microbial life that thrives in such extreme environments. The discharge produces the largest mud volcanoes on Earth, some spanning 50 km in diameter and several kilometers in height. Probing the mud volcanoes by sampling fluids from boreholes drilling into them, provides the means to examine processes that occur at depth during subduction. The subduction zone environment is the epicenter for most large earthquakes on Earth, and the fluids that flow through subduction zones can be connected with that earthquake generation. Moreover, the reactions that occur to produce the fluids provide energy that can support a wide variety of microbes, a subseafloor biosphere that is present throughout what has been referred to broadly as a "deep crustal aquifer".

The research team proposes to the sample fluids and dissolved gases from this ascending slurry in three mud volcanoes that tap different pressure (depths ranging from 10 to 20 km) and temperature conditions at depth. These ascending fluids discharge from scientific boreholes that were emplaced during International Ocean Discovery Program (IODP) Expedition 366. Prior to sampling these fluids, CORK-Lite instruments will be deployed to enable sampling operations. This infrastructure will also provide for a range of potential experimentation and monitoring efforts that can be used in the future. Specifically, the project will: (i) design, fabricate, and deploy CORK-Lites, (ii) sample discharging fluids with gas-tight and large volume sampling systems, (iii) analyze collected fluids for a range of solutes, dissolved gases, and isotopes, and (iv) measure borehole pressure and fluid discharge rates. The CORK-Lites will be sealed at the end of the field program for future experimentation and monitoring efforts. Results from this effort will test a model of abiotic methane formation, constrain the extent of serpentinization during the initial stages of subduction, set limits on potential microbial metabolic capabilities, and resolve water-rock reactions and solute sources.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Mariana Trench is the deepest location on Earth, resulting from the subduction of the Pacific Plate under the Philippine Plate. As the Pacific Plate subducts, it warms as it descends. During descent fluids that were once trapped in the pores and minerals of the Pacific Plate are liberated and react with rock in the overriding Philippine Plate to produce a slurry of mud and fluids that are very alkaline (with a pH up to 12.5, more alkaline than Clorox), yet support microbial life. This slurry ascends faults just west of the Mariana Trench and discharges at the seafloor, providing a window into processes that occur deep within the subduction channel. This discharge occurs sporadically over millions of years, producing the largest mud volcanoes on Earth, some spanning 50 km in diameter and several kilometers in height. The slurry provides the means to examine processes that occur at depth during the initial stages of subduction and by understanding reaction processes at depth, we will be able to better characterize physical, thermal, and chemical conditions within the subduction channel, which is the epicenter for most large earthquakes on Earth.

Drilling during, and prior to this NSF funding, International Ocean Discovery Program (IODP) Exp. 366 recovered material from three serpentinite mud volcanoes and installed cased boreholes with subsurface screens on each of the three summits. These boreholes represent a transect of study sites perpendicular to the trench that provide the foundation for sampling fluids and materials with increasing temperature and pressure within the subduction channel as the Pacific Plate descends. This transect was drilled to constrain the thermal and pressure conditions along the Pacific Plate, which are critical parameters in subduction models.

As part of this funded work, we participated on an ocean expedition after designing and fabricating CORK-Lites, which attach to the cased boreholes and providing a structure from which the borehole can be accessed and sampled. During the expedition we deploy three CORK-Lites, one within each of the three cased boreholes. These structures allowed us to collect fluids, conduct in situ experiments, and monitor temporal characteristics of the fluid that discharges at the seafloor. Such fluids were collected with gas-tight and large volume sampling systems and analyze for a range of solutes, dissolved gases, and isotopes. Results from this effort will test a model of abiotic methane formation in the subduction channel, constrain the extent of serpentinization during the initial stages of subduction, set limits on potential microbial metabolic capabilities, and resolve water-rock reactions and solute sources within the subduction channel.

This work will leave a legacy of infrastructure available to the international scientific community for a range of future experimentation and monitoring efforts. Continued efforts from the international community will advance understanding of plate subduction processes, microbial metabolic activity, and the possible origins of life on Earth. It will also provide the opportunity to learn about the formation processes of mud volcanism by connecting active geophysical, geochemical, geological, and microbial processes.
